title: A family member blames Riots RNG for losses in ARAM
body:
Every game i play with them that has a champ that he dislikes, he constantly rants about how broken they are, and that if the enemy team didn't get that champ they would have lost. They do this almost every game, never say gg always along the lines of:

"RIP only won because you have broken ass Malphite, or Teemo, and they should be banned on ARAM" 

When I on the otherhand feel as though it was the opposing teams superior skill and callouts which won them the game. 
They do this in other games as well, but mostly Overwatch or League of Legends, they can't seem to handle that maybe the enemy team was better, but "gg Riot, giving enemy team Veigar and Malphite, guaranteed win" is their point of view.

Is it right to report him for this?
As he always blames RNG or other people for losses and not himself in anyway shape or form.

Cheers for Response

replies.body:
Ultimately, any behaviour you find unacceptable is what you should be reporting. It may not always be actioned, but one of the functions of the report system is to act as a feedback source for Riot on what people think should be punished, even if it's something that's not currently punished.

So far as the actual behaviour in question, I'd say it's reasonably possible that it might result in a chat restriction with enough consistency (i.e. if it's happening in all/most games) and is being reported, so it may provide a good "wake up call" to your relative, at the very least to say that the behaviour isn't acceptable in-game and they need to stop.

Xayah covered the official side of things, so I'll just comment on the behaviour side.

Blaming the champion for their loss rather than accepting that sometimes (in fact roughly 50% of the time) the enemy player will just be better, is basically *the* classic example of deflection in League.

If you think about it, you probably see this behaviour elsewhere in their interactions outside of League, but essentially it's a defence mechanism. Nobody likes to admit they are wrong, and in a game like League with so many different variables that go into a match-up, blaming luck or some other uncontrollable is the easy way out. 

The number of variables involved in the League environment means it's easy to justify and therefore reinforce that impulse in this environment, so the behaviour continues. ARAM especially is going to reinforce it, because there *is* a significant (though generally not *game-defining*) degree of luck involved right from the start.

It's a pretty unhealthy behaviour, but for the most part, will only hurt them (refusing to admit mistakes basically dooms you to repeat them). Depending on your relationship with them, it may be something you want to address with them, or may not.

How you address it largely depends on the person, but logic generally isn't the way to go. You could calmly reason all you want, but if they were taking a logical/reasonable approach they wouldn't be deflecting so hard in the first place.
lowkey pathetic for you to report just because he blames rng. Glad you arent my relative.

I'll be honest, the idea that we should defend people even when they are exhibiting unhealthy behaviours and/or doing things we don't like, especially when those behaviours negatively impact others, just because they are blood-related is a rather baffling concept to me.

People aren't perfect. Sharing blood doesn't mean we should enable their harmful faults.
unhealthy is different from toxicity/something that should be banned.

My comment was not made in the context of the punishment system in League at all, nor did I imply anything about what should or shouldn't be banned in this scenario. 

I was disagreeing with the notion that we should put up with/enable unhealthy behaviour in our relatives, simply because they are related to us. Depending on the circumstance it may or may not be our (OPs in this case) responsibility to *address* the behaviour, but we certainly also have no obligation to expose ourselves to it.

The idea of calling someone pathetic for not wanting to put up with other people's unpleasantness is wildly unfair to me.
like i mentioned, "is it right for me to report them" im just looking for mostly yes or no, but constructive criticism is welcome
